awd_titl_txt: NSF/FDA SIR: Standardization of wireless coexistence testing of medical devices in the MBAN and ISM bands
awd_abstract_narration:
Abstract


#1248111
Hazem H. Refai

The number of radio-frequency (RF) wireless technologies utilized in healthcare facilities and medical devices is significantly increasing. This phenomenon brings to the forefront many issues and concerns, in particular the potential of hacking, spoofing, and interference from surrounding wireless networks. This is especially true for those operating in the license-free RF spectrum, including the Industrial, Scientific, and Medical (ISM) bands. Recognizing the potential interference among ISM devices, including those of medical use, the Federal Communication Commission (FCC) on May 17, 2012 allocated the 2.36-2.4 GHz spectrum band for Medical Body Area Network (MBAN). This spectrum will be promoted for medical devices, enabling them to operate outside the heavily used ISM bands. Although the MBAN spectrum no longer shares bandwidth with the ISM spectrum, it remains an adjacent channel. Careful evaluation of MBAN devices is necessary to avoid adjacent channel interference. 

This project proposes the development of wireless coexistence testing protocols for medical devices. Two complementing approaches will be investigated. The first approach will be characterized by an environment that incorporates a variety of wireless networks and technologies, e.g., IEEE 802.11a/b/g/n, Bluetooth, Zigbee, ultra wideband, cordless phones, and RF identification tags. Medical devices will then be evaluated for coexistence by exposing them to real-world, heterogeneous wireless networks using a prescribed methodology. The second approach will utilize vector signal generators (VSG) to emulate wireless signals. Typically, VSGs are fully configurable and able to generate a signal identical in frequency, modulation, and bandwidth to those of offending wireless signals. However, VSGs don?t implement ?listen-before-talk?, thus lacking thorough evaluation of coexistence.

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report for the General Public
Project Title: Standardization of wireless coexistence testing of medical devices in MBAN and ISM bands
PI: Hazem Refai

 

The research performed during this project developed methods to validate medical wireless coexistence. In close collaboration with FDA scientists, this research focused its efforts on multiple development activities. The first activity—essential to the success of subsequent others—was the development of software tools to aid the research team in obtaining accurate time, frequency, and power characterization of environments where wireless medical devices are likely to coexist. The second activity was the development and validation of a wireless coexistence testing protocol proven to deliver quantifiable results regarding the ability of a wireless medical device to maintain communication under variable wireless network traffic. Frequency, distance separation, and transmission power must remain constant throughout a testing occurrence. The protocol has demonstrated similar reproducible results when testing under strict noise level conditions. Currently, this methodology is the only radiated, emission-based wireless coexistence testing adapted by the ANSI C63.27 and AAMI standard committees. Third-level activities facilitated hundreds of experiments to accurately describe and evaluate the temporal characterization of the radio channel given that single-, double-, and triple-communicating terminal pairs exist within the testing environment. Probability distribution functions of channel inactivity periods were calculated under varying throughputs. Inactivity periods identify the duration required for a successful medical device to communicate its data/alarm.

Several broader impacts arose from the research work.  First, the impact of realistic coexistence assessment will greatly benefit the entire field of wireless technology, well beyond medical wireless device performance. A number of wireless electronics manufacturers and vendors implement various hardware and software designs, equipping their devices to avoid interference and coexist with other devices. Adaptive power control and adaptive clear channel assessment threshold are but a few examples of such design techniques. An environment driven coexistence assessment, such as the one developed during this project,  will help qualify and quantify designs and purported claims that vendors advertise for their devices relative to intended environments of operation. This information could be useful toward improving overall wireless device coexistence—an important factor in addressing spectrum scarcity. Second, the research work supported the education and degrees of five graduate students, including two doctoral and three masters students.  Third, two undergraduate students received training in various aspects of wireless communications and networking, programming, computer simulation algorithms, and system design while participating in the project through a number of different opportunities.
